Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> 
> 
> On 2/12/07, Robert Martin <UncleBob@... 
> <mailto:UncleBob%40objectmentor.com>> wrote:
>  > I don't feel bad about making private methods package scope in order
>  > to test them. Testing trumps encapsulation
> 
> Agreed.
> 
>  > However, if I can cover (as measured with a coverage tool) the
>  > private methods by calling public methods, I will do that rather than
>  > test the private methods explicitly.
> 
> Doesn't this implicitly imply that unit testing is optional, since you can
> achieve the same goal with functional tests?

In theory, yes; but in practice, no, because to do so requires an 
obscene number of tests. I prefer not use functional tests to verify how 
my front controller handles unrecoverable back-end errors (like a 
network disruption).

With object tests, I can easily test all possible disruptions the system 
could create with a combination of a Front Controller with a top-level 
exception handler and a crash test dummy Action object. Thinking of the 
variety of ways the back end could fail, would you like to have to write 
a functional test for each failure in each scenario? Of course, no-one 
would do this, but if you only test from request to response, and 
nowhere in the middle, that is where you'll head before long. This is 
the primary reason I've encountered for teams wanting to learn to do 
better object testing: they feel the tests they write are too numerous 
and repetitive.

Take care.
